evidence.text: The government appellants here (collectively "the Department") then moved the district court for a stay of its order pending appeal, which the district court denied.  We now deny the Department's request for a stay from our court.

extracted.value: District Court denied the Department's request for a stay (June 23, 2025).

evidence.text: First, the court determined that it had subject matter jurisdiction, rejecting the Department's argument that the case should have been brought in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims.

extracted.value: District Court granted subject matter jurisdiction, rejecting the Department's argument that the case should have been brought in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims (June 23, 2025).

evidence.text: The court specifically declined to enter an injunction and instead limited its judgments to declaratory relief.

extracted.value: District Court declined to enter an injunction and limited its judgments to declaratory relief (June 23, 2025).

evidence.text: entered two orders setting aside the new policy and related grant terminations as "illegal" under the APA.

extracted.value: District Court issued orders setting aside the new policy and related grant terminations as illegal under the APA (June 23, 2025).

evidence.text: The court entered a separate judgment in each of the two cases.

extracted.value: District Court entered separate judgments in each of the two cases (June 23, 2025).

evidence.text: issued a partial final judgment under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(b).

extracted.value: District Court issued a partial final judgment under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(b) (June 23, 2025).

evidence.text: The application for stay presented to JUSTICE JACKSON and by her referred to the Court is granted in part and denied in part.

extracted.value: Supreme Court granted in part and denied in part the application for stay presented to Justice Jackson (August 21, 2025).

evidence.text: The application is granted as to the District Court’s judgments vacating the Government’s termination of various research-related grants.

extracted.value: Supreme Court granted the application as to the District Court’s judgments vacating the Government’s termination of various research-related grants (August 21, 2025).
Supreme Court denied the application for stay in part (August 21, 2025).

evidence.source_document: Findings of Fact, Rulings of Law, and Order for Partial Separate and Final Judgment
evidence.text: the Court ruled from the bench that the Challenged Directives taken as a whole, were arbitrary and capricious final agency action, as well as were the terminations of the grants in accordance therewith; the Court took the rest of the matter under advisement. The Court

extracted.value: Court ruled that the Challenged Directives and the associated grant terminations were arbitrary and capricious, issuing a partial final judgment.

evidence.source_document: Findings of Fact, Rulings of Law, and Order for Partial Separate and Final Judgment
evidence.text: The Public Officials sought a stay pending the appeal, which this Court denied.  See Order, ‘10787 Action, ECF No. 147; Order, ‘10814 Action, ECF No. 160.

extracted.value: Court denied the stay requested by the Public Officials pending appeal.

evidence.source_document: Findings of Fact, Rulings of Law, and Order for Partial Separate and Final Judgment
evidence.text: The Court finds by a fair preponderance of the evidence that the grant terminations here at issue demonstrate an unmistakable pattern of discrimination against women’s health issues. The Court thus needs to afford the parties a chance to present evidence...

extracted.value: Court found that the grant terminations demonstrate an unmistakable pattern of discrimination against women’s health issues.
